overview: A 36-week Common Core-aligned 8th grade math course covering the Number System (8.NS), Expressions & Equations (8.EE), Functions (8.F), Geometry (8.G), and Statistics & Probability (8.SP). This is the make-or-break year before high school: students master slope, linear equations, function thinking, the Pythagorean theorem, and data interpretation. Every unit builds algebraic reasoning and justification skills that directly prepare students for Algebra 1.
naturalProgression: Boot Camp (Unit 0) diagnoses and repairs integer operations, fraction/decimal fluency, basic equations, and coordinate plane skills
Number System & Exponents (Unit 1) extends understanding to irrational numbers and builds fluency with integer exponents and scientific notation
Linear Equations (Unit 2) develops multi-step equation solving with variables on both sides, special cases, and inequalities
Graphing Linear Relationships (Unit 3) connects slope as rate of change to tables, graphs, and real-world contexts
Functions (Unit 4) formalizes the input-output relationship and introduces function comparison across representations
Systems of Linear Equations (Unit 5) applies graphing and substitution to solve real-world comparison problems
Geometry & Transformations (Unit 6) connects rigid motions to congruence, dilations to similarity, and introduces the Pythagorean theorem
Volume & Similarity Applications (Unit 7) applies volume formulas for cylinders, cones, and spheres with scaling connections
Statistics & Bivariate Data (Unit 8) builds data literacy through scatter plots, lines of best fit, two-way tables, and correlation vs causation
End-of-year spiral review and cumulative mastery assessment (Unit 9)
spiralReviewThreads: Slope & rate of change — tables, graphs, contexts: the single most important 8th grade skill
Solving equations cleanly — distribute correctly, combine like terms, check work every time
Function thinking — input → output, rules, comparison across representations
Pythagorean theorem — setup matters more than arithmetic; word problems require diagram first
Data interpretation — don't just plot, explain what it means in context

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual/physical analogies.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-3 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. The AI selects problem difficulty based on the student's current mastery.
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Guide the student through problems collaboratively. Provide hints and scaffolding as needed, but let the student do the thinking.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with support, explain reasoning, ask for help when stuck

phases.aiRole: Monitor independent practice. Only intervene if the student is stuck or making systematic errors.
phases.studentRole: Solve problems independently, self-check, explain strategies

modules.title: Start-of-Year Boot Camp
modules.preview: Diagnose and repair integer operations, fraction/decimal fluency, basic equations, and coordinate plane skills
essentialQuestions: Can I add, subtract, multiply, and divide integers without sign errors?
Am I fluent with fractions and decimals in all four operations?
Can I solve 1-step and 2-step equations and check my answer?
Can I plot and read ordered pairs on a coordinate plane?

lessons.title: Integer Operations Review
concepts: Common sign errors and how to avoid them
lessons.teachingNotes: This is the #1 source of errors all year. If students can't handle signs, every equation and expression will suffer.

lessons.title: Fraction & Decimal Fluency
concepts: Converting between fractions, decimals, and percents
Fraction/decimal equivalents students should know by heart
lessons.teachingNotes: Focus on the operations that come up most in 8th grade: multiplying/dividing fractions and converting between forms.

lessons.title: Solving 1-Step and 2-Step Equations
lessons.teachingNotes: Reinforce the balance model. Students should check EVERY answer by plugging back in.

lessons.title: Coordinate Plane Basics
concepts: Exponent rules preview (product rule, power rule)
lessons.teachingNotes: Quick preview of exponent rules to prime students for Unit 1. Don't go deep — just build familiarity.

modules.title: Unit 0 Checkpoint: Boot Camp Diagnostic
modules.preview: Diagnostic assessment of prerequisite skills with targeted intervention

modules.title: Number System & Exponents
modules.preview: Rational vs irrational numbers, integer exponent rules, and scientific notation
essentialQuestions: How do we know whether a number is rational or irrational?
Why do the exponent rules work, and how do they simplify computation?
How does scientific notation make very large or very small numbers manageable?

lessons.title: Rational vs Irrational Numbers
concepts: Approximating irrational numbers on the number line
lessons.teachingNotes: Students must be able to JUSTIFY whether a number is rational or irrational — not just identify. Writing prompt is key.

lessons.title: Integer Exponent Rules
lessons.teachingNotes: Build rules from PATTERNS, not memorization. Show 2³, 2², 2¹, 2⁰, 2⁻¹ and ask 'what's the pattern?'

lessons.title: Scientific Notation
concepts: Real-world contexts: distances in space, microscopic measurements
lessons.teachingNotes: Always ground in real contexts — 'How far is the sun?' 'How big is a red blood cell?'

modules.title: Unit 1 Checkpoint: Number System & Exponents
modules.preview: Assess rational/irrational classification, exponent rules, and scientific notation operations

modules.title: Linear Equations & One-Variable Reasoning
modules.preview: Multi-step linear equations with variables on both sides, special cases, and inequalities
essentialQuestions: How do I solve equations with variables on BOTH sides?
What does it mean when an equation has no solution or infinitely many solutions?
How do I translate a word problem into an equation or inequality?

lessons.title: Multi-Step Equations
concepts: Combine like terms on the same side
lessons.teachingNotes: The #1 error is distributing a negative incorrectly. Make students write out every step.

lessons.title: Variables on Both Sides
lessons.teachingNotes: Teach students to move variables to the side that keeps the coefficient positive when possible.

lessons.title: No Solution & Infinitely Many Solutions
concepts: Identity equations (all real numbers): same expression on both sides
Contradiction equations (no solution): false statement like 5 = 3
Recognizing special cases before solving completely
lessons.teachingNotes: Students struggle with 'how can an equation have NO answer?' Use physical analogies — if 2 apples = 3 apples, something's wrong.

lessons.title: Inequalities & Word Problems
concepts: Flip the inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative
Graphing solutions on a number line
Translating word problems to equations and inequalities
lessons.teachingNotes: Word problems are where students prove they understand what variables MEAN, not just how to push symbols.

modules.title: Unit 2 Checkpoint: Linear Equations
modules.preview: Assess multi-step equations, special cases, inequalities, and word problem translation

modules.title: Graphing Linear Relationships
modules.preview: Slope as rate of change, y = mx + b from tables/graphs/contexts, comparing linear models
essentialQuestions: What is slope, and why does it describe rate of change?
How do I write a linear equation from a graph, table, or real-world situation?
How do I compare two linear relationships to determine which is changing faster?

lessons.title: Slope as Rate of Change
concepts: Slope in real-world contexts (speed, cost per item, etc.)
lessons.teachingNotes: Slope is THE most important concept in 8th grade. Spend time here. Use real contexts: 'You earn $12/hour — what's the slope?'

lessons.title: Finding Slope from Graphs, Points, and Tables
concepts: Slope from a table (change in y / change in x)
lessons.teachingNotes: Practice finding slope in ALL representations. Students should be able to switch between them fluently.

lessons.title: Writing Linear Equations: y = mx + b
concepts: y-intercept: where the line crosses the y-axis (b = starting value)
Writing equations from slope and y-intercept
Writing equations from a graph or table
lessons.teachingNotes: Always connect b to context: 'b is what you start with BEFORE x changes anything.'

lessons.title: Comparing Linear Models
concepts: Compare slopes to determine which is changing faster
Compare y-intercepts to determine starting values
Compare from different representations (one given as graph, one as table)
Intersection meaning: 'when do they become equal?'
lessons.teachingNotes: This directly sets up systems of equations in Unit 5.

modules.title: Unit 3 Checkpoint: Graphing Linear Relationships
modules.preview: Performance task: model, graph, interpret, and compare linear relationships

modules.title: Functions
modules.preview: Function concept, identifying functions, comparing across representations, building function models
essentialQuestions: What makes a relationship a function?
How do I determine whether a table, graph, or set of ordered pairs represents a function?
How can I compare two functions given in different representations?

lessons.title: What is a Function?
concepts: Every input has exactly ONE output
Functions as machines, mappings, or rules
lessons.teachingNotes: The vending machine analogy works great: one button → one item. If one button gave you random items, that's NOT a function.

lessons.title: Identifying Functions from Representations
concepts: Tables: check for repeated x-values with different y-values
lessons.teachingNotes: Students often think 'same y-value for different x' is not a function — clarify that's fine. It's repeated x with DIFFERENT y that fails.

lessons.title: Comparing Functions Across Representations
concepts: One function given as equation, another as table/graph
lessons.teachingNotes: Heavy emphasis on mixed-representation comparison — this is a common assessment item.

modules.title: Unit 4 Checkpoint: Functions
modules.preview: Assess function identification, comparison, and modeling

modules.title: Systems of Linear Equations
modules.preview: Solve systems by graphing and substitution, interpret solutions, special cases
essentialQuestions: What does the solution to a system of equations represent?
When is graphing vs substitution the better strategy?
What does it mean when two lines never intersect or always overlap?

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Graphing
concepts: Graph both lines and find the intersection
Verify by substituting into both equations
lessons.teachingNotes: Start with the 'two plans, two prices' context — when is Plan A cheaper? Students graph both to find the crossover.

lessons.title: Solving Systems by Substitution
lessons.teachingNotes: At 8th grade level, keep substitution straightforward. Save elimination for Algebra 1.

lessons.title: Interpreting Solutions & Special Cases
concepts: Interpreting the solution in real-world context
No solution: parallel lines (same slope, different intercepts)
lessons.teachingNotes: Parallel lines = 'the two plans never cost the same.' Same line = 'the two plans are identical.'

modules.title: Unit 5 Checkpoint: Systems of Linear Equations
modules.preview: Assess systems solving by graphing and substitution with application tasks

modules.title: Geometry & Transformations
modules.preview: Rigid motions, congruence/similarity through transformations, angle relationships, Pythagorean theorem
essentialQuestions: How do transformations show that two figures are congruent or similar?
How do parallel lines and transversals create predictable angle relationships?
Why does the Pythagorean theorem work, and how do I apply it to real problems?

lessons.title: Transformations: Translations, Reflections, Rotations, Dilations
concepts: Reflection: flip over a line (x-axis, y-axis, y=x)
Dilation: scale from a center point (scale factor)
lessons.teachingNotes: Use coordinate rules so students see the algebra behind the geometry.

lessons.title: Congruence & Similarity Through Transformations
concepts: Congruent: same shape AND size (rigid motions preserve both)
Similar: same shape, different size (dilation changes size)
lessons.teachingNotes: Key insight: congruence = rigid motions only; similarity = rigid motions + dilation.

lessons.title: Angle Relationships in Parallel Lines
concepts: Parallel lines cut by a transversal
Using angle relationships to find unknown angles
lessons.teachingNotes: Students should be able to NAME the relationship and JUSTIFY why angles are equal or supplementary.

lessons.title: The Pythagorean Theorem
concepts: a² + b² = c² (c is the hypotenuse)
Distance on the coordinate plane as Pythagorean in disguise
Converse: if a²+b²=c², then it's a right triangle
lessons.teachingNotes: Draw the triangle FIRST, label the sides, THEN set up the equation. Setup matters more than arithmetic.

modules.title: Unit 6 Checkpoint: Geometry & Transformations
modules.preview: Assess transformations, congruence/similarity, angle relationships, and Pythagorean theorem

modules.title: Volume & Similarity Applications
modules.preview: Volume of cylinders, cones, spheres, and how scaling affects volume
essentialQuestions: How are the volume formulas for cylinders, cones, and spheres related?
What happens to volume when you double (or triple) the dimensions?
How do I choose the right formula and set up a real-world volume problem?

lessons.title: Volume of Cylinders
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to prisms: cylinder = circular prism. Same idea: area of base × height.

lessons.title: Volume of Cones and Spheres
concepts: Real-world problems (ice cream cones, basketballs, funnels)
lessons.teachingNotes: Demonstrate the 1/3 relationship: it takes 3 cones to fill a cylinder with the same base and height.

lessons.title: Volume Scaling & Comparisons
concepts: Scale factor k: new volume = k³ × original volume
Why doubling dimensions multiplies volume by 8
lessons.teachingNotes: The k³ scaling rule is counterintuitive — use concrete examples. 'If you double the radius of a balloon, you need 8× the air.'

modules.title: Unit 7 Checkpoint: Volume & Similarity Applications
modules.preview: Assess volume calculations, scaling, and real-world volume applications

modules.title: Statistics & Bivariate Data
modules.preview: Scatter plots, lines of best fit, two-way tables, and correlation vs causation
essentialQuestions: How does a scatter plot reveal the relationship between two variables?
What does the line of best fit tell us, and what do its slope and intercept mean in context?
Why doesn't correlation prove causation?

lessons.title: Scatter Plots: Form, Direction, Strength
concepts: Describing association: positive, negative, no association
lessons.teachingNotes: Always describe using THREE words: form, direction, strength. 'This shows a strong, positive, linear association.'

lessons.title: Line of Best Fit
concepts: Drawing an informal line of best fit
Writing the equation of the line
Using the line to make predictions (interpolation vs extrapolation)
Residuals: how far off is the prediction?
lessons.teachingNotes: At 8th grade, the line of best fit is drawn by eye — formal regression comes later. Focus on interpretation.

lessons.title: Interpreting Slope & Intercept in Data Contexts
concepts: Slope meaning: 'For every 1 unit increase in x, y increases/decreases by m'
Intercept meaning: 'When x is 0, y is b' (does it make sense in context?)
lessons.teachingNotes: Tie directly to slope work from Unit 3. This is the PAYOFF for all that slope practice.

lessons.title: Two-Way Tables & Correlation vs Causation
concepts: Joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies
lessons.teachingNotes: Use funny/memorable examples for correlation vs causation: 'Ice cream sales and drownings both go up in summer — does ice cream cause drowning?'

modules.title: Unit 8 Checkpoint: Statistics & Bivariate Data
modules.preview: Assess scatter plot interpretation, line of best fit, two-way tables, and data reasoning

modules.title: End-of-Year Spiral Review & Mastery
modules.preview: Mixed review by standard cluster, targeted reteach, and cumulative assessment preparation
essentialQuestions: Which standard clusters are my strongest, and which need targeted review?
Can I apply multiple skills together to solve complex, multi-step problems?
Am I ready for Algebra 1?

lessons.title: Review: Functions & Linear Relationships
concepts: y = mx + b from all representations

modules.title: 8th Grade Math Final Mastery Assessment
modules.preview: Comprehensive assessment covering all Common Core 8th grade math standards
